title: What does France export to the US?
summary: Certain French sectors are especially reliant on exports to the United States and risk being hit hard by the 20% tariffs announced by Donald Trump on Wednesday.

title: Trump defiant as tariffs send world markets into panic: 'I think it's going very well'
summary: Across the globe, stock markets plummeted after President Donald Trump unveiled harsh levies Wednesday aimed at countries he claims have 'ripped off' the United States. When asked about the market as he left the White House on Thursday, he said the 'markets are going to boom.'

title: Pentagon watchdog to probe use of Signal app to discuss air strikes
summary: Several officials from the Trump administration used the messaging app Signal to talk about strikes on Houthi rebels in Yemen. It came to light when a journalist was accidentally added to the chat.

title: Marco Rubio on a mission to reassure Europeans about NATO
summary: While he spoke less harshly than the Pentagon chief, Pete Hegseth, in mid-February, the US secretary of state, visiting NATO headquarters in Brussels on Thursday, nonetheless urged NATO members to significantly increase their defense spending to reach 5% of their gross domestic product in the medium term.

title: French nursery worker gets 25 years for killing baby with drain cleaner
summary: Myriam Jaouen, 30, admitted in police custody that she had given the infant the corrosive liquid, but insisted that she had not intended to kill her. She was charged with murder but the court in the southeastern city of Lyon found her guilty of 'torture' and 'barbarism resulting in death.'

title: 'The rush to retire stems from a loss of meaning and prospects at work'
summary: Talks between labor unions and employers' organizations about the future of France's pension system appear to be at an impasse. In his last column before retiring, Le Monde's Philippe Escande suggests a solution could be making both pensions and the retirement age more progressive.

title: World reacts to Trump's tariffs with retaliation threats and fears for the global economy
summary: After Donald Trump's latest tariffs on countries around the world, EU head Ursula von der Leyen spoke against a 'major blow to the world economy,' and Emmanuel Macron called for suspending investments in the US.

summary: On Wednesday, April 2, Washington announced additional 34% tariffs on goods imported from China.

summary: The French president will meet humanitarian and security workers next Tuesday in Arish, a transit point for international aid intended for Gaza.

title: Trump's tariffs: Companies compete in ingenuity to cut costs
summary: Some companies are hunting for exceptions within regulations, risking heavy fines in case of misinterpretation.

title: Tariffs: The risk of uncontrollable escalation
summary: By imposing 'reciprocal' tariffs on imports from countries around the world, Donald Trump exposes the US to retaliatory measures from its trade partners and risks throwing the global economy into a recessionary spiral.

summary: The statement came as Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is visiting the country, despite an international arrest warrant against him over the war in Gaza.

summary: Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said he wanted to implement Donald Trump's plan, which involves evicting Palestinians from Gaza.

title: Trump doesn't know it, but his protectionist hero, McKinley, ended up changing his stance
summary: To justify his trade war, Donald Trump has referred to former president William McKinley, a protectionist who was in office at the turn of the 20th century. However, what is less known is that McKinley ended up regretting his aggressive trade policy, writes Le Monde columnist Pascal Riché.

title: Gordon Parks, the American photographer who observed Americans in Paris
summary: Known for his photographs of the civil rights movement, Gordon Parks spent two years in the French capital for 'Life' magazine, from 1949 to 1951. Here, he captured images of American expatriate teenagers and the haven Paris represented for Black artists. Several of his works are included in the 'Paris Noir' exhibition at the Centre Pompidou.

title: Europe thinks about how to reduce dependence on US within NATO
summary: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio was to attend his first meeting at NATO headquarters in Brussels on Thursday and Friday. The discussions among allies focus on the 'rebalancing' of funding and operational responsibilities.

summary: On Wednesday, April 2, Donald Trump announced new 20% tariffs on products coming from the European Union.

title: Putin's delay tactics stall talks with US over Ukraine truce
summary: Despite Donald Trump's early concessions to Russia, peace talks have stalled, and the only progress – a deal to halt strikes on infrastructure – remains largely ineffective.

title: South Korea's Constitutional Court removes President Yoon Suk Yeol from office
summary: The court issued the verdict more than three months after the opposition-controlled National Assembly voted to impeach the former prosecutor. South Korea must hold a national election within two months to find a new president.

title: At least 22 bear cubs born in the Pyrénées in 2024: A record threatened by 'low genetic diversity'
summary: The bear population in the mountain range, which is at least 96, is steadily increasing. This does not seem to impact the number of attacks on sheep and cattle herds.

title: New York City Mayor Eric Adams will skip Democratic primary and run as an independent
summary: Adams announced his decision to run for reelection as an independent following intense speculation in the wake of his recently dismissed criminal case: 'I have to be realistic.'

title: Signal: An app rooted in a fierce struggle against surveillance
summary: The encrypted messaging app has been in the spotlight due to the Trump administration's problematic use of it. Yet, this incident highlights the 'success story' of an application built on strong convictions about privacy.

title: Mirror bacteria could 'eliminate life on Earth.' Should all research in this area be banned?
summary: Could these hypothetical organisms wreak havoc on the world if biologists manage to create them? After a collective of scientists called for a worldwide debate in 'Science,' Le Monde took stock of this apocalyptic scenario.

title: China responds to Trump's tariffs with trade measures and a WTO lawsuit
summary: China responded to US President Donald Trump's new customs duties by measures such as imposing the same 34% tariff rate on bilateral trade, expanding export controls and filing a suit with the World Trade Organization.

title: Benjamin Netanyahu's complete impunity

summary: Just months before its opening in a temporary space in eastern Paris, the MansA, envisioned by President Emmanuel Macron, is still awaiting funding from the Ministry of Culture.

summary: As Russian forces prepare to launch a new military offensive in the coming weeks, a Kremlin envoy has indicated that outstanding issues are stalling ceasefire talks.

title: In Ukraine, gamers make the best drone pilots
summary: Now more deadly than any other weapon, drones have changed the face of the fighting between Kyiv and Moscow. Pending a solution to the conflict, Ukraine is focusing on training and recruiting the people who make the best pilots: gamers.

title: 'Trump and Afghanistan are the perfect illustration of America withdrawing into itself'
summary: The US government's ending of a visa program for people who helped America during the war against the Taliban is just the latest indignity of a withdrawal that was negotiated during Trump's first term, says Le Monde columnist Alain Frachon.
